item.title: Starting a blog(down)
item.description:
Starting a blog

Having learnt lots from the open source community over the past years, from blogs and videos to attending meetups and awesome conferences, I have decided to start a blog myself and share some of the things I find interesting. Essentialy it will boil down to using open source tools to build cool things with data.

It’s easy

You can get your blog up and running with literally three lines of R code. I have first heard about the blogdown package on Twitter, and to see if the rumours were true, I went on to download the current build from Github, using devtools::install_github('rstudio/blogdown').

Under the hood, blogdown uses Hugo to generate the website, but wraps most functionality nicely, so there’s no need for much manual configuration during the process, if at all.

Setup

We first create a folder for our blog on our computer, and set it as our home directory by setwd("path-to-blog") inside RStudio. Now we simply run:

# 1 if you haven't already, install blogdown
devtools::install_github('rstudio/blogdown')
# 2 install hugo
blogdown::install_hugo()
# 3 create new site
blogdown::new_site()

That’s it. You now have a complete folder structure initialized in your working directory:

And a new site running on your localhost, that you can see in RSutdio’s Viewer, or inside your browser by clicking Show in new window in the top right corner of your Viewer.

You future blog posts will reside in the content/post folder. Here we find two dummy posts as .Rmd files that we can start editing straight away and see the results immediately after saving. Because everytime you save changes, your site is instantly rebuilt. If you come back to work on your existing site, you can simply run serve_site() and see your site regenerated according to your latest edits.

Customization

Now we can now begin to customize the look of our blog by installing a theme using the function install_theme('username/theme'). For my site, I picked nishanths/cocoa-hugo-theme which I like very much for its minimalistic design. You can browse other themes on themes.gohugo.io/.

Configuration

The only thing left to do now is to edit the config.toml file to set the name of your blog, avatars, or even link a Google Analytics account if the theme allows for. The file contains parameters such as:

title        = "Tamas Szilagyi"
baseurl      = "http://tamaszilagyi.com/"
relativeurls = true
languageCode = "en-us"
theme        = "cocoa-hugo-theme"
faviconfile  = "img/leaf.ico"
github       = "//github.com/mtoto"
highlightjs  = true
avatar       = "img/profile_pic.png" 
...

If you are going to include R codechunks in your posts, also don’t forget to set highlightjslanguages = ["r"]. When the blog is ready, we run build_site() to compiles the files to html and build the website. What we need for deployment will reside under the public/ folder.

Deployment

Again, publishing is a piece of cake. There are multiple ways for conveniently publishing a blogdown site, and being somewhat familiar with Github Pages, that’s what I went for. I created a new repository named mtoto.github.io and simply pushed the contents of public/ to the master branch.

The website should be almost immediately available at the same address as the repo name. If you want an url other than username.github.io however, you will need to sign up with a hosting provider. Then put a file in the public/ called CNAME with a one liner containing your blog url such as www.mywebsite.com. After, you push this file to Github and ask your provider to point your domain to the github pages url.

And voilà, we have ourselves a full functioning static website that looks great, is easy to manage and as portable as it gets may you decide to switch for different hosting solutions.
